title: GDP data confirm eurozone in double-dip doldrums
text:

CBU is taking a short break on Monday and will be back on Wednesday

Get the latest worldwide picture with our vaccine tracker

Latest news

  • Coronavirus infections in the UK are back down to the levels of last summer with about one in 1,000 people infected, according to official data (BBC)

  • US personal incomes rose at a record rate in March thanks to government stimulus cheques

  • A UK study showed the elderly were still at risk of dying from Covid-19 despite being vaccinated

For up-to-the-minute coronavirus updates, visit our live blog

Eurozone data this morning confirmed expectations that the bloc is experiencing a double-dip recession, as GDP fell 0.6 per cent from the previous quarter, following a fall of 0.7 per cent in the final three months of 2020.

The bloc-wide figures mask some striking variations. Germany was hardest hit, shrinking 1.7 per cent, while France managed to increase growth by 0.4 per cent, thanks to rises in construction and household consumption.

Separate figures showed eurozone inflation rising from 1.3 per cent to 1.6 per cent in April. Unemployment has also improved slightly, albeit with numbers flattered by people who have stopped seeking work or are on government-supported furlough schemes.

The overall state of eurozone recovery lags behind the US, which yesterday recorded growth for the same period of 1.6 per cent, and China, which this month reported an increase of 0.6 per cent.

Today is also, theoretically at least, the deadline for member states to submit their economic recovery plans for EU approval. The European Commission will have two months to assess the schemes before funds are released.

As our Europe Express newsletter reports, some remain optimistic that pent-up demand will lead to an “economic resurrection” in the forthcoming quarter. Katharina Utermöhl, an economist at German insurer Allianz said: “The consumer is in the starting blocks and just waiting for the starting gun. Then we'll see a super boom.”

Global economy

Joe Biden's stimulus programme, the loosening of lockdown and the rapid pace of coronavirus vaccinations helped the US economy record growth of 1.6 per cent in the first quarter — or an annualised 6.4 per cent — enabling the president to proclaim America was “ready for take-off”. Federal Reserve chief Jay Powell said on Wednesday that the bank was still “a long way from our goals” as it kept interest rates and bond-buying strategies on hold. Catch up on our series published throughout the week: Biden's first 100 days

UK household wealth reached new heights during the pandemic, according to official data. Rising house prices, which hit a new record today, and the improved value of pensions were among the factors driving net wealth to £11.4tn or £172,000 per person. 

The UN said on Friday that the combination of Covid-19 and the military coup risked pushing half the population of Myanmar, already one of the poorest countries in Asia, into poverty. The military seizure of power and its aftermath have also derailed the country's vaccination programme.

Business

West coast editor Richard Waters reports on surging first-quarter profits in Big Tech and expectations that the coronavirus-driven boom will last way beyond the pandemic. “Consumers once valued choice, but what they value now is dependability,” said one analyst on how companies such as Alphabet, Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Microsoft have become the bedrock of business life. There are downsides to living our lives online: clinical psychologist Monique Moore writes on the damage “retail therapy” can have on our mental health.

More banks reported impressive first-quarter results as provisions for bad loans were scaled back. BNP Paribas recorded net profits up 38 per cent to €1.8bn; NatWest reported pre-tax profits rising to £946m from £519m; Standard Chartered rose 18 per cent to $1.4bn, even as it took a hit from the decline in retail banking accelerated by the pandemic; and Barclays profits almost tripled to £1.7bn from £605m last year. The Lex opinion column is bullish on UK banks' future. Several with back offices in India, the world's largest outsourcing location, are pulling out to relieve pressure on the country as it struggles with a vast second wave of infections.

Exxon and Chevron sprang back to profit in the first quarter thanks to rising crude prices, following the huge losses incurred when markets collapsed last year. Moody's rating agency this week forecast “sustained momentum in commodity prices” for the next year.

Markets

The price of Copper, a key material for electrical devices and expected to play an important part in the switch to green energy, passed a 10-year high to hit $10,000 a tonne. The soaring prices have boosted traders such as Glencore.

A Morgan-Stanley owned fund has won some big bets on markets staying calm after the frenzy of the pandemic period. The Parametric fund has been dubbed the “Gamma Hammer” after the Greek term used to describe how the value of options fluctuates as stocks move. One portfolio manager warned of the dangers of a big move, meaning the trade could “get smoked because you are effectively collecting pennies in front of a steamroller”.

Declarations from the Federal Reserve that it was in no rush to wind down its bond-buying programme failed to stop the global bond rout resuming after the publication of strong US GDP data.

The essentials

Hopes are rising that global travel may soon be able to resume, but finding a common standard for “vaccine passports” is a complicated process. FT writers look at international efforts to solve the problem. London's Heathrow airport said it would struggle to cope with coronavirus checks if overseas travel resumed in May. Holiday destinations are trying everything from vaccinations on arrival to cash bonuses to lure tourists back.

Have your say

DeadCat Flounce comments on We're still in the dark about insecure work:

In the same way that every generation thinks they are the first to discover sex, this generation appears to think it is the first to experience precarious employment. They seem completely unaware of “the lump” in the construction industry or the conditions of dock workers in the past. Instead, they have the impression that everyone in the 1970s, 1980s and 1990s was in a ‘job for life' with a final salary pension. That, frankly, is nonsense. I had a job where I worked 48 weeks a year, then was fired for 4 weeks over Christmas, just to be rehired again. The whole thing was done to avoid giving me full employment rights. None of this is acceptable of course — and I welcome this article — but many of the comments below the line appear to think these issues only started in 2008. They certainly did not.

Final thought

This weekend's How to Spend It magazine is a special edition on the theme of hope, guest-edited by designer Jonathan Anderson. It includes film-maker Adam Curtis on optimism in a pessimistic age, favourite pick-me-ups from creatives, and actor Dan Levy on the joy of making playlists.
